choices.text: As an adjunct in pulmonary embolectomy

questions.text: What is an alternative use of cardiopulmonary bypass?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cardiopulmonary bypass is also used in profound hypothermia, pulmonary embolism surgery, and severe cardiopulmonary trauma management.

  • According to Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, while cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) is primarily used in cardiac surgery to maintain circulation and oxygenation during open-heart procedures, it also has several important alternative/emergency uses:
    • Profound hypothermia:
      • CPB is used for rewarming, especially when the core temperature drops below 28°C.
      • It allows gradual and controlled rewarming with restored perfusion.
    • Pulmonary embolectomy:
      • In cases of massive pulmonary embolism, CPB can act as a temporary circulatory support during surgical removal of the embolus, especially when the patient is hemodynamically unstable.
    • Cardiopulmonary trauma:
      • Severe blunt or penetrating chest trauma can lead to combined cardiac and pulmonary failure.
      • CPB can be a life-saving bridge to definitive repair or recovery.
  • Thus, all of the listed uses are recognized and practiced as alternative indications for cardiopulmonary bypass.

Surgical approach to the heart

questions.text: What approach to the heart is commonly used for cardiopulmonary bypass?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Median sternotomy provides optimal exposure to all cardiac chambers and great vessels and is the standard approach for cardiopulmonary bypass. 

  • Median sternotomy is the most commonly used and preferred approach for surgeries involving cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB).
  • It allows direct, wide, and symmetrical access to the heart and the major great vessels (aorta, pulmonary artery, superior and inferior vena cava), which is essential for establishing the CPB circuit and performing complex cardiac surgeries such as valve replacements and CABG.
  • It also facilitates exposure of both atria and ventricles, making it ideal for a wide variety of cardiac procedures requiring CPB.
  • The approach involves a vertical midline incision through the sternum, which can be easily extended if needed.

Explanation of other options:

Left lateral thoracotomy (Option B): This is typically used for accessing the descending thoracic aorta or left lung, not suitable for central cardiac structures.

Right lateral thoracotomy (Option C): Used in some specific right-sided heart procedures, but offers limited exposure and is not the standard for CPB.

Subxiphoid approach (Option D): Used for pericardial access or drainage, not for major cardiac surgeries or CPB - exposure is very limited.

choices.text: End hole in venous pipe sits in IVC
Side hole in venous pipe sits in left atrium
Side hole in venous pipe sits in portal vein
End hole in venous pipe sits in right atrium

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding venous cannulation during cardiopulmonary bypass?
questions.solution:
• A purse-string suture is placed around the right atrial appendage and a single 'two-stage' venous cannula is placed to establish venous drainage.
  • The venous pipe has end holes that sit in the inferior vena cava and side holes that sit in the right atrium (to take drainage from the superior vena cava).
  • Alternatively, the superior and inferior vena cavae may be cannulated separately to gain better control over the venous return and to facilitate surgery within the right atrium.
  • Venous drainage from the femoral vein can offer an alternative, particularly during thoracic aortic or minimally invasive procedures.

Venous cannulation during CPB

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 59, Cardiac Surgery, Pg: 945.

questions.text: Which artery is not cannulated in cardiopulmonary bypass?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The radial artery is too small and not suitable for cannulation in cardiopulmonary bypass.

  • In cardiopulmonary bypass, arterial cannulation is essential to return oxygenated blood from the bypass machine to the patient's circulation.
  • The most common site for arterial cannulation is the ascending aorta, due to its proximity and size. (Option A ruled out)
  • In certain situations (e.g., redo surgery, extensive aortic disease), alternative sites are used, such as the femoral artery or axillary artery, both of which are large and accessible enough to handle the high-flow demands of CPB. (Options B, D ruled out)
  • The radial artery, however, is too small in diameter to accommodate the large-bore cannulae required for CPB.
  • It is commonly used for arterial pressure monitoring, but not for perfusion cannulation.
  • Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, clearly mentions the preferred cannulation sites - ascending aorta, femoral artery, and axillary artery - with no mention of the radial artery for CPB cannulation.

choices.text: Intermittent cross clamp fibrillation and total circulatory arrest

questions.text: What methods can be used for infusion of cardioplegic solution for myocardial protection?
questions.solution:
• The methods of myocardial protection include intracoronary infusion of a cardioplegic solution (antegrade), infusion via the coronary sinus (retrograde), intermittent cross-clamp fibrillation and total circulatory arrest.
  • Intermittent cross-clamp fibrillation is a technique in which intermittent ventricular fibrillation is induced by a small electrical charge. The heart does not eject and is relatively still but not bloodless. The aorta is cross-clamped to render the heart ischaemic. The heart can tolerate short periods (10-20 min) of ischaemia, provided the heart is reperfused when the cross-clamp is released and allowed to beat following cardioversion for short periods during the operation.
  • Total circulatory arrest becomes necessary when visibility and clarity of the operative area is crucial, as in paediatric surgery or in surgery of the ascending aorta and arch of the aorta. CPB is instituted and the core body temperature reduced to 15-18°C (profound hypothermia). The metabolic rate of all organs of the body is reduced by 50% with every 7°C drop in temperature. Using this technique, circulatory arrest can be tolerated for up to 20-30 min. Additional cerebral protection can be provided with ice packs placed around the head, pharmacological agents and cerebral perfusion techniques.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 59, Cardiac Surgery, Pg: 945 -946

questions.text: What are the complications of cardiopulmonary bypass?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cardiopulmonary bypass can lead to systemic complications, including infection, pancreatitis, and air embolism, among others.

  • Cardiopulmonary bypass, while life-saving, is associated with a range of systemic and procedure-related complications due to factors like non-physiological circulation, contact activation of blood with artificial surfaces, ischemia-reperfusion injury, and hemodilution.
  • Recognized complications include:
    • Infection:
      • Surgical site infections (e.g., mediastinitis), pneumonia, and line sepsis can occur due to prolonged surgery and ICU stay.
    • Pancreatitis:
      • A rare but known complication, thought to be due to hypoperfusion and ischemia of the pancreas during bypass.
    • Air embolism:
      • Occurs if air enters the CPB circuit or is introduced inadvertently during de-airing of the heart; can lead to neurological injury or death.
  • Other complications may include acute kidney injury, coagulopathy, neurocognitive dysfunction, and systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS).

questions.text: The most commonly bypassed artery during CABG surgery is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The left anterior descending (LAD) artery is the most frequently involved in atherosclerosis and thus the most commonly bypassed artery in CABG. 

  • The left anterior descending (LAD) artery is the most critical vessel in terms of supplying a large portion of the anterior wall, septum, and apex of the left ventricle - all of which are vital for cardiac function.
  • The LAD is also most frequently involved in coronary artery disease due to its anatomical course and shear stress dynamics.
  • Consequently, CABG most commonly involves bypassing the LAD, typically using the left internal mammary artery (LIMA) because of its excellent long-term patency.
  • Bypassing the LAD improves survival outcomes more significantly than other grafts, making it the priority during CABG.

Explanation of other options:

Left posterior descending (Option B): Not a standard coronary artery; likely a confusion with the posterior descending artery (PDA), which usually arises from the right coronary artery or occasionally from the circumflex in left dominance. It's less commonly bypassed than LAD.

Circumflex artery (Option C): Although often involved in coronary disease, it is not bypassed as frequently as the LAD and has a variable course.

Right marginal branch (Option D): This branch of the right coronary artery supplies a smaller region and is bypassed less commonly.

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for ischemic heart disease except?
questions.solution: Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 59, Cardiac Surgery, Pg: 948.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with exertional chest pain radiating to the left arm. His ECG shows nonspecific ST-T changes. To confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of suspected coronary artery disease (CAD), which of the following is considered the gold standard diagnostic modality?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Coronary angiography is the gold standard for diagnosing and evaluating the severity and exact location of coronary artery disease.

  • Coronary angiography remains the gold standard for the diagnosis of coronary artery disease (CAD).
  • It is an invasive imaging technique where contrast is injected directly into the coronary arteries, allowing precise visualization of the location, extent, and severity of atherosclerotic lesions.
  • This technique is essential not only for diagnosis but also for guiding revascularization strategies, such as percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) or coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).
  • It helps in identifying lesions amenable to stenting versus those requiring surgical bypass.
  • While non-invasive methods are used for initial evaluation and risk stratification, definitive diagnosis and treatment planning still rely on angiography.

Explanation of other options:

Cardiac MRI (Option A): Excellent for myocardial viability and function assessment, but not used as a first-line or gold standard for CAD diagnosis.

Stress Echocardiography (Option B): Non-invasive test useful for functional ischemia assessment, but lacks anatomical detail; used for screening and pre-test probability evaluation.

PET scan (Option D): Used for assessing myocardial perfusion and viability, especially in ischemic cardiomyopathy, but not standard for routine CAD diagnosis.

choices.text: It demonstrates the extent, severity, and location of stenosis
Demonstrates quality and size of the distal arterial tree
Reduction in diameter >50% is considered severe

questions.text: A 61-year-old man with chronic stable angina is undergoing evaluation to determine the extent of coronary artery disease and potential need for revascularization. Coronary angiography is planned. Regarding this investigation, which of the following statements is NOT correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A >70% reduction in luminal diameter is considered hemodynamically significant and severe, not >50%.

  • Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition states that coronary angiography is the gold standard investigation for assessing coronary artery disease.
  • It identifies:
    • The site, extent, and severity of coronary stenosis
    • The quality and size of the distal coronary tree, which is important for determining whether bypass grafting is feasible
    • The suitability for surgery is defined by defining which vessels are diseased and whether they are bypassable
  • However, the severity of a coronary artery stenosis is determined by functional and anatomical significance. In general:
    • A >50% luminal narrowing is considered moderate
    • A >70% reduction is considered severe and hemodynamically significant, especially in major vessels like the LAD
    • For the left main coronary artery, a >50% stenosis is considered severe, due to its critical importance
  • Therefore, Option D is incorrect because it generalizes >50% as severe for all vessels, which is not accurate.

choices.text: >50% stenosis proximal left anterior interventricular artery
Two or three main coronary artery diseases
Poor ventricular function associated with multivessel disease

questions.text: All of the following are indications for surgery in coronary artery disease except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Surgical intervention is not typically indicated for isolated right coronary artery disease, even if critical; other options represent established indications for coronary artery bypass surgery.

  • Indications for surgical revascularization (CABG) in patients with coronary artery disease, especially when the disease is extensive, affects critical vessels, or is associated with impaired ventricular function.
  • Indications for CABG include:
    • Significant left main coronary artery stenosis (>50%) (Option A ruled out)
    • Proximal LAD (left anterior descending) disease, especially with >50% stenosis
    • Two or three-vessel disease, particularly if associated with left ventricular dysfunction or diabetes (Option C ruled out)
    • Poor ventricular function with multivessel disease, where surgery improves survival and symptoms (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which is the most common graft used as a conduit for CABG?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The long (great) saphenous vein is the most frequently used conduit in CABG due to its length, accessibility, and ease of harvest.

  • The great (long) saphenous vein remains the most commonly used graft in CABG procedures, particularly for venous conduits.
  • It is favored because:
    • It is long and straight, allowing multiple grafts to be harvested from a single limb
    • It is easily accessible with minimal morbidity
    • It provides sufficient diameter to match the coronary arteries
  • Despite a lower long-term patency compared to arterial grafts like the internal mammary artery, the great saphenous vein remains a mainstay, especially when multiple grafts are required or arterial conduits are unsuitable.
  • The left internal mammary artery (LIMA) is often used for the LAD, but among vein or other extra-arterial conduits, the long saphenous vein is used most often.
  • As LIMA-LAD anastomosis avoids the late complication of vein graft atherosclerosis, particular interest has focused on the use of bilateral internal mammary artery (BIMA) grafts.
  • However, there is ongoing debate regarding the appropriateness in certain subgroups of patients, such as the obese diabetic, in whom sternal wound complications appear higher.

Explanation of other options:

Short saphenous vein (Option B): Incorrect - rarely used due to shorter length and more variable anatomy.

Radial artery (Option C): Used as an arterial conduit, but less commonly than the saphenous vein and LIMA; requires preoperative assessment of collateral hand circulation.

Axillary artery (Option D): Not used as a graft conduit - may be used for arterial cannulation in CPB, but not for bypass grafting.

questions.text: Conduit of choice for LAD in CABG?
questions.solution:
• The left internal mammary artery (LIMA), or internal thoracic artery, has become the conduit of choice for the LAD.
  • As LIMA-LAD anastomosis avoids the late complication of vein graft atherosclerosis, particular interest has focused on the use of bilateral internal mammary artery (BIMA) grafts.
  • However, there is ongoing debate regarding the appropriateness in certain subgroups of patients, such as the obese diabetic, in whom sternal wound complications appear higher.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 59, Cardiac Surgery, Pg: 951.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male is undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). The surgical team discusses arterial conduits in the operating room. Which of the following arterial grafts can be used in CABG?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Multiple arterial grafts, including LIMA, radial artery, and inferior epigastric artery, can be used in CABG as alternative or additional conduits.

  • Arterial grafts are often used in coronary artery bypass grafting due to their superior long-term patency compared to venous grafts.
  • The left internal mammary artery (LIMA) is the most preferred arterial graft, especially for the left anterior descending artery.
  • The radial artery is also commonly harvested and provides good medium- to long-term patency when properly prepared and protected from spasm.
  • The inferior epigastric artery, though less commonly used, is a valid option, especially when other conduits are unsuitable or unavailable.
  • All these arteries have been successfully used as conduits for bypassing obstructed coronary vessels.

questions.text: Which is the most common type of arrhythmia in a postoperative CABG patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common postoperative arrhythmia is sinus tachycardia, closely followed by atrial fibrillation (AF). Atrial fibrillation is the most frequent arrhythmia occurring after CABG, typically within the first few days postoperatively.

  • Postoperative arrhythmias are a common complication after CABG, with atrial fibrillation (AF) being the most prevalent, occurring in approximately 20-40% of cases.
  • It usually develops within 2-4 days post-surgery and is often transient.
  • Contributing factors include atrial irritation, inflammation, hypoxia, electrolyte imbalance, and sympathetic stimulation. Management
  • Management typically involves rate or rhythm control and anticoagulation if AF persists.
  • While other arrhythmias may occur, none are as common or as clinically significant as atrial fibrillation in the postoperative setting.

Explanation of other options:

Atrial flutter (Option B): Although atrial flutter may occur postoperatively, it is significantly less common than atrial fibrillation in CABG patients.

Ventricular fibrillation (Option C): This is a life-threatening arrhythmia that can occur in the setting of acute ischemia or infarction but is not commonly seen as a postoperative complication after stable CABG procedures.

Ventricular flutter (Option D): A rare and unstable arrhythmia that typically transitions into ventricular fibrillation; not commonly reported in post-CABG patients as a frequent arrhythmia.

choices.text: Neonates and adults with irreversible respiratory failure
As bridge therapy for patients who may need VAD
All of the above are uses of ECMO

questions.text: All of the following are uses of ECMO except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

ECMO is not indicated in irreversible respiratory failure, as it is reserved for potentially reversible conditions.

  • ECMO (Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation) provides temporary life support in patients with severe cardiac or respiratory failure unresponsive to conventional therapies.
  • It acts by externally oxygenating and circulating the blood, giving time for the lungs or heart to recover or for bridging to definitive therapy (e.g., transplant or VAD).
  • However, irreversible respiratory failure is an absolute contraindication.
  • ECMO is not curative; it supports gas exchange or circulation until the underlying cause improves.
  • Using it in irreversible cases offers no survival benefit and adds risk.
  • ECMO is used as a bridge to longer-term support devices like Ventricular Assist Devices (VAD) in patients with severe cardiac failure.
  • ECMO is frequently used post-operatively when patients cannot be weaned from cardiopulmonary bypass due to myocardial dysfunction.

choices.text: Through an anterior submammary incision, the LIMA can be dissected down
More medial incisions allow access to other coronary vessels

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with stable angina is scheduled for a less invasive procedure instead of conventional CABG. The cardiac surgeon discusses an approach that avoids full sternotomy and allows for LIMA harvesting through a small incision. Regarding Minimally Invasive Direct Coronary Artery Bypass (MIDCAB), which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Access to other coronary vessels through more medial incisions is not feasible in MIDCAB, which is primarily limited to LAD.

  • MIDCAB is a surgical technique used for bypassing the left anterior descending (LAD) artery without the need for full sternotomy or cardiopulmonary bypass.
  • A small left anterior thoracotomy (submammary or intercostal) is made, and LIMA (Left Internal Mammary Artery) is dissected through this incision and anastomosed to the LAD.
  • It is a useful option for high-risk patients or those with isolated LAD disease.
  • Patient selection is essential because not all coronary arteries are accessible via this limited incision. (Option C ruled out)
  • Only anterior structures like LAD can be reached reliably.
  • Attempts to access other vessels through more medial incisions are not generally feasible in MIDCAB.
  • Through an anterior submammary incision, the LIMA can be dissected down. This is the standard approach for MIDCAB. (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: All of the following are advantages of homograft use for valve surgery except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Homografts are not readily available due to limited donor sources and complex preparation procedures.

  • Homografts (also known as allografts) are human donor heart valves harvested from cadavers and preserved for surgical use, often employed in aortic valve or root replacement, especially in cases of infective endocarditis.
  • Their biological nature offers key advantages:
    • They closely replicate the native valve in structure, leading to excellent haemodynamics, and being non-thrombogenic, they eliminate the need for lifelong anticoagulation, unlike mechanical valves. (Options A, C, D ruled out)
  • However, the major drawback of homografts is their limited availability.
  • They require specialized tissue banks for cryopreservation, and donor tissue supply is low, making them far less accessible than commercially manufactured mechanical or bioprosthetic valves.
  • Therefore, despite their benefits, homografts are not considered readily available, which is the exception in the given list.

choices.text: Prophylactic antibiotics are required for patients with prosthetic valves undergoing a dental procedure
All patients with mechanical valves require warfarin
Warfarin usually starts on the first or second post-operative day
The use of anticoagulants in patients with biological valves depends on the patient's underlying rhythm postoperatively

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding postoperative management in valve surgery except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Prophylactic antibiotics are recommended, not required, for patients with prosthetic valves undergoing certain dental procedures.

  • Post-operative management after valve surgery involves balancing thromboprophylaxis and infection prevention.
  • While mechanical valves universally require long-term anticoagulation (usually with warfarin), bioprosthetic valves may need anticoagulation for a short period, particularly in the presence of atrial fibrillation or other thromboembolic risks. (Option D ruled out)
  • Warfarin is typically initiated early (within the first or second day) after surgery in patients receiving mechanical valves to prevent thrombus formation. (Option C ruled out)
  • Mechanical prosthetic valves are highly thrombogenic, necessitating lifelong anticoagulation with warfarin. (Option B ruled out)
  • Regarding infective endocarditis prophylaxis, guidelines recommend prophylactic antibiotics in patients with prosthetic heart valves undergoing invasive dental procedures that involve manipulation of gingival tissue or perforation of the oral mucosa.
  • However, it is not universally required for all dental procedures and must be considered on a case-by-case basis.
  • Thus, saying it is "required" in all situations is inaccurate.

questions.text: A 34-year-old pregnant woman in her third trimester presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to her back. Her blood pressure is 180/110 mmHg. On auscultation, a diastolic murmur is heard over the left sternal border. Chest X-ray shows a widened mediastinum. Which of the following is a known risk factor for the condition suspected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The condition the patient presents with is Aortic dissection. Aortic dissection is associated with multiple risk factors, including hypertension, connective tissue disorders like Marfan syndrome, and pregnancy.

  • Aortic dissection involves a tear in the intimal layer of the aorta, allowing blood to enter and create a false lumen between the layers of the vessel wall.
  • It is a life-threatening condition and presents classically with acute chest or back pain.
  • Hypertension is the most common risk factor as it increases shear stress on the aortic wall.
  • Marfan syndrome, a connective tissue disorder, leads to weakening of the aortic media, predisposing the patient to dissection even in the absence of hypertension.
  • Pregnancy, especially in the third trimester, increases hemodynamic stress and hormonal changes that affect the integrity of the aortic wall, thereby raising the risk of dissection in susceptible individuals.

questions.text: Identify the Stanford type of aortic dissection in the image shown below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Stanford type B aortic dissection involves only the descending aorta and does not extend proximally to involve the ascending aorta.

  • The Stanford classification system divides aortic dissection into two types:
    • Type A involves the ascending aorta and may extend into the arch or descending aorta.
    • Type B is confined to the descending aorta distal to the left subclavian artery without any involvement of the ascending aorta.
  • In the image provided, the dissection flap is seen beginning distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery, sparing the ascending aorta, making this a classic Stanford type B dissection.
  • Stanford B dissections are generally managed medically unless there is evidence of complications such as rupture, malperfusion, or persistent pain.

Explanation of other options:

Stanford A (Option A): Involves the ascending aorta, which is not seen in this case.

Stanford I (Option C): Not part of the Stanford classification; may be confused with the DeBakey classification.

Stanford II (Option D): Also not part of the standard Stanford classification; DeBakey Type II involves only the ascending aorta.

questions.text: Which is the most common benign cardiac tumour in children?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rhabdomyoma is the most common primary benign cardiac tumor in children, especially infants, and is strongly associated with tuberous sclerosis.

  • Rhabdomyomas are the most frequent benign cardiac tumors in the pediatric population, accounting for over 60% of cardiac tumors in neonates and infants.
  • These tumors are hamartomatous in nature and composed of immature cardiac myocytes.
  • They are often multiple, located predominantly in the ventricular walls or interventricular septum, and may regress spontaneously over time.
  • Rhabdomyomas are strongly associated with tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC), an autosomal dominant genetic disorder characterized by hamartomas in multiple organs.
  • Around 50-80% of children with cardiac rhabdomyomas have TSC.
  • Clinically, they can be asymptomatic or may present with arrhythmias, heart failure, or obstruction of blood flow, depending on size and location.
  • Most lesions are diagnosed prenatally or in early infancy via echocardiography.
  • Due to their benign nature and tendency to regress, many rhabdomyomas require only observation unless they cause hemodynamic compromise or refractory arrhythmias.
  • In such symptomatic cases, surgical resection may be considered.

Fetal Cardiac Rhabdomyoma:

questions.text: Which is the most common type of benign cardiac tumour in adults?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Atrial myxoma is the most common benign primary cardiac tumor in adults, most frequently arising in the left atrium.

  • Atrial myxomas are the most common primary cardiac tumors in adults, accounting for approximately 50% of all benign cardiac tumors.
  • They usually arise from the interatrial septum in the left atrium, typically at the border of the fossa ovalis.
  • These tumors are gelatinous, pedunculated masses that may be sessile or mobile, and they can prolapse into the mitral valve orifice during diastole, leading to mitral valve obstruction, mimicking mitral stenosis clinically.
  • Symptoms can be variable, including:
    • Dyspnea, orthopnea, syncope (due to obstruction)
    • Embolic events (systemic embolism if left-sided)
    • Constitutional symptoms like fever, weight loss, and arthralgia, due to cytokine production (especially IL-6)
    • Tumor plop may be heard on auscultation-a low-pitched early diastolic sound.
  • Diagnosis is primarily by echocardiography (especially transesophageal), which can demonstrate the mass and its mobility.
  • Treatment is surgical excision, which is usually curative.
  • Recurrence is rare unless it's familial (as seen in Carney complex-which includes multiple myxomas, lentigines, endocrine tumors).

Atrial myxoma:

Explanation of other options:

Angioma (Option B): Angiomas are benign vascular tumors, rarely found in the heart. They are more common in the skin, liver, or CNS.

Rhabdomyoma (Option C): Rhabdomyomas are the most common benign cardiac tumors in children, not adults. Frequently associated with tuberous sclerosis.

Leiomyoma (Option D): Leiomyomas are benign smooth muscle tumors typically found in the uterus (fibroids), not commonly seen in the heart.

choices.text: Below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle
This will ideally find the fifth space

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. He is in respiratory distress, and auscultation reveals decreased breath sounds on the right side. A chest X-ray confirms a large right-sided pneumothorax. You prepare for the insertion of an intercostal chest drain. Which of the following statements regarding the safest site for chest drain insertion is NOT correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Placing the chest tube below the level of the nipple increases the risk of intra-abdominal injury and is not considered safe.

  • The safe triangle is the recommended site for inserting an intercostal chest drain to minimize the risk of damaging internal structures.
  • This anatomical region is bounded by:
    • Anterior border: lateral edge of pectoralis major (Option C ruled out)
    • Posterior border: anterior border of latissimus dorsi
    • Inferior border: line above the fifth intercostal space (usually at nipple level in males)
    • Superior border: base of the axilla
    • The ideal site lies in the 5th intercostal space, anterior to the mid-axillary line, and just above the rib to avoid the neurovascular bundle located at the inferior border of the rib. (Option A, D ruled out)
  • Inserting below the nipple risks entering the peritoneal cavity, especially in children or lean adults, and may injure abdominal organs.

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is used for pleurodesis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All three listed techniques, pleurectomy, pleural abrasion, and chemical pleurodesis, can be used to achieve pleurodesis by eliminating the pleural space.

  • Pleurodesis is a medical procedure performed to adhere to the parietal and visceral pleura, thereby obliterating the pleural space and preventing recurrent pleural effusions or pneumothorax.
  • It can be performed using:
    • Chemical pleurodesis:
      • Most commonly used in clinical practice involves the instillation of chemical agents (e.g., talc, doxycycline, bleomycin) into the pleural space to cause inflammation and fibrosis.
      • It is preferred in patients unfit for surgery.
    • Mechanical pleurodesis (pleural abrasion):
      • During thoracoscopy, the parietal pleura is abraded to induce inflammation and adhesions.
    • Pleurectomy:
      • Surgical removal of part of the parietal pleura, often used in recurrent or resistant cases-especially in younger patients with spontaneous pneumothorax.
  • All these techniques aim to prevent recurrence by eliminating the potential space where air or fluid may accumulate.

choices.text: Pleural involvement with primary or secondary malignancy

questions.text: A 64-year-old chronic smoker presents with progressive dyspnea and right-sided chest heaviness for the past 2 weeks. Chest X-ray shows a large right-sided pleural effusion. Thoracocentesis reveals hemorrhagic fluid with malignant cells on cytology. Which of the following is NOT a cause of malignant pleural effusion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Congestive heart failure causes transudative effusion and is not a malignant cause of pleural effusion.

  • Malignant pleural effusion (MPE) occurs due to the presence of malignant cells in the pleural space or obstruction of pleural lymphatics by a malignancy.
  • The clinical presentation includes dyspnea, cough, and chest pain. Diagnosis is confirmed via pleural fluid cytology or pleural biopsy.
  • The common mechanisms include direct pleural invasion by a tumor, hematogenous spread to pleura, or obstruction of mediastinal lymphatics.
  • Lung cancer is the most common cause of MPE, followed by breast cancer and lymphomas.
  • Malignant cells may arise from primary pleural tumors (e.g., mesothelioma) or secondaries.
  • Mediastinal lymph node metastasis may block lymphatic drainage, leading to effusion.
  • Congestive heart failure (CHF) typically causes bilateral transudative effusions due to increased hydrostatic pressure, and it is not classified under malignant causes.

Malignant pleural effusion:

choices.text: It is end stage of pleural infection from any cause
It can be results from complication of any thoracic operation
Pathological diagnosis requires the presence of thick pus with a thick cortex of fibrin and coagulum over the lung
Fibro purulent phase is first phase

questions.text: All of the following are correct regarding empyema except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The first phase of empyema is the exudative phase, not the fibro-purulent phase.

  • Empyema refers to the collection of pus in the pleural cavity, often due to an unresolved pneumonia, trauma, or post-surgical complication. (Option B ruled out)
  • The pathological evolution of empyema occurs in three distinct stages:
    • Exudative phase (early stage):
      • Clear or straw-colored sterile fluid collects in the pleural space.
      • This phase is dominated by the accumulation of protein-rich fluid due to increased vascular permeability.
    • Fibro-purulent phase (intermediate stage):
      • Fibrin deposition occurs.
      • Pus and inflammatory cells accumulate.
      • Loculations may form as fibrin strands compartmentalize the pus.
    • Organizing phase (late stage):
      • A thick, inelastic fibrinous peel (cortex) forms over the lung, limiting expansion.
      • Pathological diagnosis requires the presence of thick pus with a thick cortex of fibrin and coagulum over the lung (Option C ruled out)
      • This is the end stage of pleural infection and may require decortication. (Option A ruled out)
  • Empyema can indeed result as a complication of any thoracic surgery, such as lobectomy or pneumonectomy.
  • Diagnosis is often clinical, but grossly purulent pleural fluid and imaging (e.g., ultrasound, CT chest) assist in confirming the diagnosis.

Empyema:

questions.text: Which one of the following conditions can predispose to empyema formation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All the listed conditions can directly or indirectly lead to infection of the pleural space, resulting in empyema.

  • Empyema refers to the accumulation of pus in the pleural cavity and is typically a complication of infections or trauma that extends into the pleural space.
  • Several pathological conditions can predispose a patient to empyema formation:
    • Bronchiectasis:
      • This chronic lung condition involves permanent dilation of bronchi with repeated infections and pooling of mucus, which can lead to pneumonia and subsequent pleural space infection (empyema).
    • Penetrating injury:
      • Chest trauma that breaches the pleural space may introduce pathogens directly, leading to infection and empyema.
    • Subphrenic abscess:
      • An abdominal abscess beneath the diaphragm (usually post-surgical or due to visceral perforation) can spread infection through lymphatics or directly across the diaphragm into the pleural space.
  • Therefore, all the mentioned conditions are recognized risk factors for empyema.

choices.text: If lung fails to re-expand after drainage of empyema, decortications may be required
The fibrous cortex from the entrapped underlying lung is removed
This procedure usually performed through medial sternotomy
Both visceral and parietal cortex removed

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding decortications except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Decortication is typically performed via thoracotomy or VATS, not through a median sternotomy.

  • Decortication is a surgical procedure done to remove the restrictive fibrous layer (the cortex) overlying the lung, chest wall, and diaphragm when the lung is trapped due to chronic empyema or other pleural pathologies. (Option B ruled out)
  • It is usually indicated when the lung fails to re-expand following drainage of an empyema or when organized fibrous tissue prevents normal lung expansion, leading to restrictive lung disease. (Option A ruled out)
  • The procedure involves removing both the parietal and visceral fibrous cortex to allow the lung to expand again and restore its function. (Option D ruled out)
  • Thoracotomy is the most common approach used, or Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery (VATS) in some centers.
  • Median sternotomy, however, is reserved for central mediastinal access, typically in cardiac surgeries, and is not the standard approach for decortication.

choices.text: Flexible bronchoscopy can be performed under local anesthesia
Rigid bronchoscopy is ideal for therapeutic maneuver
Rigid bronchoscopy can be done only in awake patients
Biopsies are relatively small and suction is limited with flexible bronchoscopy

questions.text: All of the following are correct regarding bronchoscopy except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rigid bronchoscopy requires general anesthesia and cannot be performed in awake patients.

  • Bronchoscopy is a vital tool in both diagnostic and therapeutic pulmonary procedures.
  • There are two types: rigid and flexible.
  • Flexible bronchoscopy is typically done under local anesthesia with or without sedation, is more versatile in accessing distal airways, and is ideal for diagnostic purposes (biopsy, BAL, brushings). (Option A ruled out)
  • It is often performed with topical lidocaine and mild sedation.
  • The channel size of flexible scopes limits both suction power and biopsy sample size compared to rigid scopes. (Option D ruled out)
  • Rigid bronchoscopy, performed under general anesthesia, provides a wider lumen, making it ideal for removing foreign bodies, controlling massive hemoptysis, placing stents, and debulking tumors. (Option C ruled out)
  • It is not feasible in awake patients due to the need for airway control and patient immobility.
  • Hence, option C is incorrect as rigid bronchoscopy cannot be done in awake patients.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the use of bronchoscopy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bronchoscopy is both a diagnostic and therapeutic tool used for biopsy, secretion removal, and foreign body retrieval.

  • Bronchoscopy is a procedure that allows direct visualization of the tracheobronchial tree using either a flexible or rigid bronchoscope.
  • It serves several purposes:
    • Diagnostic:
      • To collect tissue samples (biopsies), brushings, and bronchoalveolar lavage for evaluating infections, tumors, or interstitial lung diseases.
    • Therapeutic:
      • To remove thick secretions (especially in critically ill or ventilated patients), aspirated foreign bodies (especially in children), or to control bleeding.
  • Flexible bronchoscopy is usually done under local anesthesia with mild sedation, while rigid bronchoscopy requires general anesthesia and is better for large foreign body removal and airway stenting.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of cancer death?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related mortality globally in both men and women.

  • Lung cancer remains the most common cause of cancer death worldwide, accounting for approximately 25% of all cancer-related deaths.
  • The high mortality is due to several factors:
    • Often diagnosed at an advanced stage
    • Strong association with tobacco smoking
    • Aggressive behavior and frequent metastasis
    • Limited early detection methods
  • Although the incidence of lung cancer in men is decreasing in some countries due to reduced smoking, it continues to be a major health burden due to its high case fatality rate.
  • In contrast, while prostate cancer is common, it usually progresses slowly and is more often diagnosed at an early stage, making mortality lower. (Option B ruled out)
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is a leading cause of cancer death in some regions (especially Asia and Africa due to chronic hepatitis), but not globally. (Option C ruled out)
  • Gallbladder cancer has high mortality but is relatively rare. (Option D ruled out)
  • It contributes to cancer deaths in specific regions (like Northern India and South America), but is not a common cause of cancer death globally.

choices.text: Incidence of NSCLC is more than SCLC
Small cell lung cancer also known as oat cell cancer
Squamous cell carcinoma is most common type of NSCLC
Squamous cell carcinoma typically appears as cavitating tumours

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding lung cancer, except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Adenocarcinoma, not squamous cell carcinoma, is the most common type of NSCLC.

  • Lung cancer is broadly divided into non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and small cell lung cancer (SCLC).
  • NSCLC accounts for approximately 85% of all lung cancers and includes adenocarcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and large cell carcinoma.
  • Among NSCLC subtypes, adenocarcinoma is the most common, especially in non-smokers and women, and tends to arise peripherally in the lungs.
  • Squamous cell carcinoma, historically more common in smokers, typically arises centrally and can form cavitating lesions due to central necrosis.
  • SCLC (also known as oat cell carcinoma) is highly aggressive, with early metastasis and a strong association with paraneoplastic syndromes.

Histological classification of lung cancer:

  • Small cell lung cancerswere known as oat cell cancers because of the packed nature of small, dense cells.
    • They are a type of neuroendocrine tumour (NET) and represent about 20% of all lung cancers.
    • They tend to metastasize early to lymph nodes and by blood-borne spread. The median survival is measured in months.
    • The tumours are very responsive to chemotherapy, such that median survival may be doubled (although it is still short), but they are rarely, if ever, cured.
    • Surgery is rarely offered unless in a very limited stage disease.
  • Adenocarcinomais now the most common of the NSCLC types, having overtaken squamous cancer.
    • The increasing incidence is partly due to an increasing incidence in women and may be the result, in part, of a move towards lower-tar cigarettes that are inhaled more deeply to get the same effect.
  • Squamous carcinomatypically appears as a cavitating tumour.
  • Large cell undifferentiatedis a discrete histological type of NSCLC and is included within NETs.
  • Bronchioalveolar carcinoma(BAC), also known as adenocarcinoma-in-situ, has a distinct pattern of growth following the pre-existing pulmonary architecture and is thus much less dense; it appears as a patchy diffuse shadow ('ground glass') on radiographs rather than a solid mass and has a histological appearance to match.

choices.text: It includes small cell cancer and large cell undifferentiated lung cancer
They are slow growing and highly vascular
Segmental or wedge resection may be sufficient for small peripheral tumour

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding neuroendocrine tumours of the lung except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Most neuroendocrine tumors of the lung are not highly malignant—typical carcinoids are usually low-grade.

  • Neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) of the lung represent a spectrum of neoplasms ranging from low-grade typical carcinoids to highly malignant small cell lung carcinoma (SCLC).
  • The World Health Organization (WHO) classifies pulmonary NETs into four major types: typical carcinoid, atypical carcinoid, large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma (LCNEC), and small cell lung carcinoma (SCLC). (Option A ruled out)
  • Typical carcinoids: Well-differentiated, slow-growing, low-grade tumors with a good prognosis. For small, peripheral, typical carcinoid tumors, limited resections like wedge or segmental resection may be adequate, especially in patients with limited pulmonary reserve. (Options C, D ruled out)
  • Atypical carcinoids: Intermediate-grade tumors with more aggressive behavior.
  • SCLC and LCNEC: Poorly differentiated, high-grade tumors with aggressive clinical courses.
  • Although SCLC and LCNEC are highly malignant, the majority of neuroendocrine tumors (particularly carcinoids) are not, making option C incorrect.

Lung neuroendocrine tumors according to subtype.

A: typical carcinoid tumor,

B: atypical carcinoid tumor,

C: large-cell neuroendocrine carcinoma, and

D: small-cell lung carcinoma.

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic smoker presents with cough, weight loss, and occasional blood in sputum. On examination, he has digital clubbing and reduced breath sounds on the right. What is the likely symptom of lung cancer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lung cancer commonly presents with haemoptysis, dyspnoea, and clubbing, among other systemic and respiratory symptoms.

  • Lung cancer may present with a wide variety of symptoms depending on tumor location, size, and presence of metastasis.
  • Haemoptysis (coughing up blood) results from tumor invasion into bronchial blood vessels.
  • Dyspnoea may arise due to airway obstruction, pleural effusion, or parenchymal involvement.
  • Clubbing is a common paraneoplastic feature associated with chronic lung conditions, especially bronchogenic carcinoma.
  • Other signs and symptoms include persistent cough, chest pain, weight loss, hoarseness (due to recurrent laryngeal nerve involvement), and symptoms of paraneoplastic syndromes.

Clinical features

  • The site of the lesion.
  • The invasion of neighbouring structures;
  • The extent of metastases.
  • Common symptoms include a persistent cough, weight loss, dyspnoea, and non-specific chest pain.
  • Haemoptysis occurs in fewer than 50% of patients presenting for the first time.
  • Cough, or a changed cough, is a common presentation but non-specific in this population.
  • Severe localised pain suggests chest wall invasion with the infiltration of an intercostal nerve. Invasion of the apical area may involve the brachial plexus, leading to Pancoast's syndrome.
  • Dyspnoea may come from loss of functioning lung tissue, lymphatic invasion, or the development of a large pleural effusion.
  • Pleural fluid is an ominous feature, and the presence of blood in a pleural effusion suggests that the pleura has been directly invaded.
  • Clubbing and hypertrophic pulmonary osteoarthropathy accompany some lung cancers and may resolve with excision of the primary lesion.
  • Invasion of the mediastinum may result in hoarseness (because of recurrent laryngeal nerve involvement), dysphagia (because of the involvement of, or extrinsic pressure on, the oesophagus), and superior vena caval obstruction.
  • Small cell carcinoma is associated with the development of myopathies, including the Eaton-Lambert syndrome, which is similar to myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the most common benign tumour of the lung?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hamartoma is the most common benign tumor of the lung, often detected incidentally on imaging.

  • Pulmonary hamartomas are benign lung tumors composed of a disorganized mixture of tissues normally found in the lung, such as cartilage, fat, and connective tissue.
  • They are the most common benign tumors of the lung, accounting for approximately 6-8% of all solitary pulmonary nodules.
  • Hamartomas are typically asymptomatic and found incidentally on chest imaging. A
  • A characteristic radiologic feature is "popcorn calcification", seen on CT, representing cartilage or fat within the lesion.
  • While granulomas can also appear as solitary pulmonary nodules, they are not true neoplasms but rather areas of inflammation and healing, commonly due to infections like tuberculosis or fungal infections.

BENIGN LUNG TUMOURS

  • Benign tumours of the lung are uncommon and account for fewer than 15% of solitary lesions seen on chest radiographs.
  • A peripheral tumour usually causes no symptoms until it is large; a central tumour may present with haemoptysis and signs of bronchial obstruction while still small.
  • A tumour is likely to be benign if it has not increased in size on chest radiographs for more than 2 years or if it has some degree of calcification; however, a tissue diagnosis is usually pursued.
  • Most benign nodules are granulomas (tuberculosis or histoplasmosis).
  • The most common benign tumour is a hamartoma, a developmental abnormality containing mesothelial and endothelial elements.
  • Diagnosis (and definitive treatment) is achieved by excision of the lesion.
  • Any of the mesodermal elements of the lung may form a mesodermal tumour (chondroma, lipoma, leiomyoma).
  • Deposits of amyloid may have a similar radiographic appearance to a nodule (pseudotumour).

Lung Hamartoma:

Explanation of other options:

Granuloma (Option A): Granulomas are common causes of lung nodules but are not true benign tumors; they result from chronic inflammation.

Lymphoma (Option B): Lymphomas are malignant neoplasms of lymphoid origin and are not classified among benign lung tumors.

Chondroma (Option D): Chondromas are rare benign tumors of cartilage origin in the lung; much rarer than hamartomas.

questions.text: Which is the most common primary mediastinal tumour?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Thymoma is the most common primary tumor of the mediastinum, particularly arising in the anterior mediastinum.

  • The mediastinum is anatomically divided into anterior, middle, and posterior compartments, and each has characteristic tumors.
  • Thymomas are the most common primary mediastinal neoplasms, typically arising in the anterior mediastinum, especially in adults aged 40-60 years.
  • These tumors originate from the epithelial cells of the thymus and may be benign or malignant.
  • Thymomas are often associated with paraneoplastic syndromes, most notably myasthenia gravis.
  • On imaging, they may appear as a well-defined anterior mediastinal mass, and diagnosis is confirmed by histopathology.

Explanation of other options:

Neurogenic tumour (Option B): These are the most common posterior mediastinal tumors, not anterior. They arise from nerves (e.g., schwannomas, neurofibromas).

Germ cell tumour (Option C): These can occur in the anterior mediastinum but are less common than thymomas. They include teratomas, seminomas, and non-seminomatous tumors.

Lymphoma (Option D): Lymphomas are also found in the anterior and middle mediastinum, but they are not as common as thymomas as primary mediastinal tumors. Hodgkin's lymphoma may present here, especially with mediastinal widening.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is diagnosed with a thymoma. Imaging reveals dissemination to the pleura and pericardium. Based on the Masaoka staging system, what is the most appropriate stage for this thymoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Masaoka Stage IVA indicates pleural or pericardial dissemination of thymoma.

  • The Masaoka staging system is the most commonly used clinical staging system for thymoma, based on the extent of invasion.
  • It correlates well with prognosis and guides management.
  • The stages are:
    • Stage I: Completely encapsulated tumor, no invasion beyond capsule.
    • Stage II: Microscopic or macroscopic invasion into surrounding fatty tissue or mediastinal pleura.
    • Stage III: Macroscopic invasion into neighboring organs such as the pericardium, lung, or great vessels.
    • Stage IVA: Pleural or pericardial dissemination.
    • Stage IVB: Lymphogenous or hematogenous metastasis (e.g., to distant lymph nodes or organs).
  • In this case, pleural or pericardial seeding without distant spread fits Stage IVA.

choices.text: Suspicious lesion on chest radiograph in which neoplasia cannot be excluded

questions.text: All of the following are indications for surgery in tuberculosis, except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Surgery is not indicated when a tuberculous abscess is responding well to chemotherapy.

  • Surgical intervention in tuberculosis is typically reserved for cases where medical therapy is insufficient or where there are complications that cannot be managed conservatively.
  • Indications for surgery include suspicion of malignancy, persistent cavities with complications like aspergilloma, or life-threatening haemoptysis.
  • However, if a tuberculous abscess is responding to anti-TB drugs, there is no need for surgery as the medical management is effective.
  • Surgery would only be considered in case of failure of medical therapy or complications such as rupture or persistent infection.
